solution_line_template: The total percentage of money that Reese spent in February and March is {february_percentage}% + {march_percentage}% = {total_percentage_spent_feb_mar}%.
This means the April expenses and the money left in her account make up {total_percentage_base}% - {total_percentage_spent_feb_mar}% = {remaining_percentage}% of her savings.

Reese had ${money_left} + ${april_expenses} = $<<{money_left}+{april_expenses}={amount_corresponding_to_remaining_percentage}>>{amount_corresponding_to_remaining_percentage} for the April expenses and the money left in her account.

So, ${amount_corresponding_to_remaining_percentage} is equal to {remaining_percentage}% which means every 1% is equal to ${amount_corresponding_to_remaining_percentage}/{remaining_percentage} = $<<{amount_corresponding_to_remaining_percentage}/{remaining_percentage}={value_per_percent}>>{value_per_percent}.
Therefore, Reese originally had ${value_per_percent} x {total_percentage_base} = $<<{value_per_percent}*{total_percentage_base}={original_savings}>>{original_savings} in her savings account.
